skill.name: cirq
skill.description: Quantum computing framework for building, simulating, optimizing, and executing quantum circuits. Use this skill when working with quantum algorithms, quantum circuit design, quantum simulation (noiseless or noisy), running on quantum hardware (Google, IonQ, AQT, Pasqal), circuit optimization and compilation, noise modeling and characterization, or quantum experiments and benchmarking (VQE, QAOA, QPE, randomized benchmarking).

security_audit.summary: Reviewed seven documentation files with 3018 lines. No code reads sensitive files or harvests environment variables. Network and token references are instructional examples only.

content.value_statement: Quantum circuit work is complex and easy to misconfigure. This skill provides structured guidance for building, simulating, and running circuits with Cirq.
actual_capabilities: Design Cirq circuits with standard gates and measurement keys
Run state vector and density matrix simulations
Perform parameter sweeps and expectation value estimation
Model noise with depolarizing and custom noise models
Prepare workflows for Google, IonQ, Azure, AQT, and Pasqal hardware
limitations: Requires Cirq and provider packages to be installed separately
Hardware execution needs valid provider credentials and access
Large simulations can be memory intensive and slow
Does not fetch calibration data unless user supplies API access

use_cases.title: Learn core Cirq patterns
use_cases.description: Build simple circuits, run simulations, and interpret measurement histograms with clear steps.

use_cases.title: Prototype noisy experiments
use_cases.description: Add noise models, compare results across noise levels, and evaluate mitigation ideas.

use_cases.title: Prepare hardware runs
use_cases.description: Validate circuits, optimize for gatesets, and submit jobs to supported providers.

prompt_templates.title: First circuit
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a two qubit Bell state circuit in Cirq and explain the expected measurement histogram.

prompt_templates.title: Parameter sweep
prompt_templates.prompt: Show a parameterized single qubit circuit with a sweep over theta and explain how to read the results.

prompt_templates.title: Noisy simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a plan to compare circuit performance across three depolarizing noise levels using Cirq.

prompt_templates.title: Hardware ready compile
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline steps to optimize a circuit for a hardware gateset and validate it before submission.

output_examples.input: Explain how to run a noisy simulation and interpret results
output: Define a noise model and apply it to the circuit
Run a density matrix simulation with repetitions
Compare histograms across noise levels to see degradation
Report which states remain dominant and why

best_practices: Test on simulators before hardware runs
Use parameter sweeps for efficient exploration
Validate circuits against device constraints early
anti_patterns: Running large density matrix simulations without memory checks
Submitting hardware jobs without circuit validation
Using unrealistic noise models for analysis

faq.question: Is this compatible with my environment?
faq.answer: It works with Python and Cirq installed. Hardware providers need their specific Cirq extensions.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: Simulation scales exponentially with qubits and noise models can increase runtime.

faq.question: How do I integrate with hardware?
faq.answer: Install the provider package, configure credentials, and use the provider service API shown in the guide.

faq.question: Does it access my data or keys?
faq.answer: No. It only describes how to set credentials if you choose to use hardware providers.

faq.question: What if simulations are slow or fail?
faq.answer: Reduce qubit count, avoid dense noise models, or switch to a faster simulator type.

faq.question: How does it compare to other tools?
faq.answer: Cirq focuses on circuit design, simulation, and hardware integration, while other frameworks may target different ecosystems.
